In terms of mitigation, without reductions in overall anthropogenic emissions, increased reliance on
based mitigation was predicted, which would add to the many already competing
demands on land. However, some mitigation measures were suggested to not compete with other land
uses, while also having multiple co
Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). As in AR5, there was large uncertainty surrounding
mitigation within AFOLU, in part because current carbon stocks and fluxes
the highly context specific applicability of measures

ers, insufficient policy, lack of incentivisation and institutional support to

None the less, the importance of mitigation within AFOLU was highlighted

carbon management). This CDR component was deemed crucial to limit climate change
and its impacts, which would otherwise lead to enhanced release of carbon from land.
SRCCL emphasised that mitigation cannot be pursued in isolation. Th
adapt to climate change, but also deal with land degradation and
desertification, while enhancing food and fibre security, biodiversity and contributing to other SDGs
Boundaries, scope and changing context of the current report
This chapter assesses GHG fluxes between land and the atmosphere due to AFOLU, the associated
drivers behind these fluxes, mitigation response options and related policy, at time scales of 2030 and
2050. Land and its management has important links with oth
er sectors and therefore associated chapters
within this report, notably concerning the provision of food, feed, fuel or fibre for human consumption
(Chapter 10) and industry (Chapter 11). Mitigation within these sectors may in part, be
dependent on contributions from land and the AFOLU sector, with interactions between all sectors
